awd_titl_txt: MRI:  Acquisition of an Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer (IRMS) to enable interdisciplinary research at Dartmouth and beyond
awd_abstract_narration:
An award is being made to Dartmouth College to support the acquisition of an Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer (IRMS) and associated equipment to measure the major stable isotopes of C, N, O, S, and H, both at natural abundance and enriched levels. The acquisition of this IRMS will make isotopic techniques more readily available to a wide range of departments at Dartmouth College and other New England colleges, which will ultimately increase faculty research productivity, undergraduate and graduate research capabilities, and the potential for interdisciplinary collaborations amongst a variety of departments and institutions.  Advanced undergraduate students will have the opportunity to run the IRMS to promote STEM training and career advancement. 

The IRMS will be used for research that advances understanding of the global carbon cycle in the past, present, and future. Isotopic analyses have become standard in many fields of biological and geological research. Stable isotopes are used to test and make inferences about past climates and ancient carbon cycling, to understand the connections within aquatic and soil food webs, and to trace the movement of carbon, nitrogen, and contaminants from plants into soils and then into aquatic systems and the atmosphere. Researchers at Dartmouth are currently developing techniques to use carbon isotope analyses and respiration quotients to partition soil respiration into sources by specific compound classes.  Such analyses have the potential to allow a more mechanistic understanding of respiration, the largest flux of carbon from the terrestrial biosphere to the atmosphere. Researchers are also working to define unique carbon and hydrogen isotopic signatures for methane produced during the breaking of carbon-phosphorus bonds to better understand methane sources in marine and lacustrine environments. Results from these research efforts will be published in peer-reviewed scientific journals, presented at scientific meetings, and used in public outreach activities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The goal of this project was to set up and initiate operations of a multi-departmental stable isotope mass spectrometry user facility at Dartmouth College. The Dartmouth stable isotope lab (DartSIL) will serve students, researchers, and faculty from across Dartmouth and nearby small colleges in New England. At Dartmouth, stable isotopes are used to test and make inferences about past climates and ancient carbon cycling, to understand the connections within aquatic and soil food webs, and to trace the movement of carbon, nitrogen, and contaminants from plants into soils and then into aquatic systems and the atmosphere. DartSIL makes isotopic techniques more readily available in northern New England, ultimately increasing faculty research productivity, undergraduate and graduate research capabilities, and the potential for interdisciplinary collaborations amongst a variety of departments and institutions.

We purchased an Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer (IRMS; DELTA V Plus Mass Spectrometer) and peripherals (GASBENCH-II with carbonate option, Flash IRMS Elemental Analyzer IsoLink CNSOH with autosampler, and Gas Chromatograph IsoLinkII CH+TraceGC 1310, and a ConFlo-IV Interface), to analyze 2H/1H, 13C/12C, 15N/14N, 18O/16O, or 34S/32S stable isotope ratios in gaseous (e.g., methane, carbon dioxide), solid (e.g., carbonates, organic matter, gypsum), and liquid (e.g., dissolved inorganic carbon, water) samples. We renovated a room in the Dartmouth College's Life Sciences Center to house the instrument. The renovations included changes to the HVAC system to allow proper venting of the instrument, new gas cabinets and wall-mounted regulators, and changes to the electrical infrastructure to connect the instrument to an uninterrupted power supply with back-up battery power and a built-in transformer.

The DartSIL instruments are now installed and will begin running samples once our training on the instruments is complete. Training has been delayed due to the COVID pandemic. In anticipation of DartSIL's opening, multiple graduate and undergraduate students have been trained in isotopic techniques and sample preparation. Hundreds of samples have been prepared to run on the IRMS. Thus far, these samples are coming from three different departments (Biology, Earth Sciences, and Anthropology) at Dartmouth demonstrating interdisciplinary use of the instruments. Dartmouth researchers have received multiple grants from the National Science Foundation and Department of Energy that will utilize the instruments in their research activities. Lastly, a graduate level course on isotopic techniques is being planned to train students from multiple departments on the instruments through guided individual and group projects.

 


Last Modified: 12/21/2021
Modified by: Caitlin E Hicks Pries

Image
  • IRMS and peripherals in place during install in LSC, February 2020. (RIGHT) Technical staff J. Landis, Thermo Engineer B. Holmes and P.I. C. Hicks-Pries during the March 2020 installation.
    William Leavitt
    Copyrighted
    Caitlin E Hicks Pries
    The Dartmouth Stable Isotope Lab (DartSIL)
